Expectation1: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation1: An emergency diversion cuts across three sectors at once, requiring rapid multi-sector coordination.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story:
I sat in the control tower, headset pressed to my ear, eyes darting between radar screens. An emergency diversion was unfolding—an aircraft needed to cut across three sectors, and I was the point of contact. My colleagues expected me to coordinate swiftly, to keep the airspace safe and traffic flowing. The pressure was immense; every second counted.

At the same time, the communal event for controllers was underway in the break room. The aroma of catered food drifted in, and my stomach reminded me I hadn’t eaten since dawn. But as I glanced at the spread, I realized none of it was kosher-certified. The expectation from my family and community was clear: I should observe kosher laws, even if it meant going hungry.

My radio crackled with urgent voices, demanding my full attention. Yet, the sight of my colleagues laughing and sharing plates gnawed at me. I felt torn—between the duty to my team and the commitment to my faith. The demands pressed in from both sides, and I sat frozen, wrestling with which expectation I could bear to disappoint.
